comments.body: Not sure of those dates, what with leap year and all, but probably close enough.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +180,184 @@   s       second           +/- 2.9e11 years        [2.9e11 BC, 2.9e11 AD]
   ms      millisecond      +/- 2.9e8 years         [ 2.9e8 BC,  2.9e8 AD]
   us      microsecond      +/- 2.9e5 years         [290301 BC, 294241 AD]
   ns      nanosecond       +/- 292 years           [  1678 AD,   2262 AD]
   ps      picosecond       +/- 106 days            [  1969 AD,   1970 AD]

comments.body: Why? 10 days goes into a week zero times--I copy pasted your suggested example, and that's the answer I got on this feature branch. Seems consistent with `small_operand % larger_operand` more broadly producing `small_operand`, no?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +121,125 @@
    >>> np.timedelta64(1,'W') % np.timedelta64(10,'D')
    numpy.timedelta64(7,'D')

There are two Timedelta units ('Y', years and 'M', months) which are treated
